Metadata: Stressed-out lobsters: crustacean hyperglycemic hormone and stress proteins

"Integrative and Comparative Biology," 45:43-50, 2005; "Ecophysiology and Conservation. The Contribution of Endocrinology and Immunology," annual meeting of the Society of Integrative and Comparative Biology, New Orleans, Louisiana, January 5-9, 2004.

Organisms in natural habitats must frequently respond to changes in their environments through various physiological mechanisms. The author's laboratory has developed several methods for the quantification of stress in crustaceans. An ELISA was developed for the crustacean hyperglycemic hormone (CHH) from the American lobster ("Homarus americanus"). It is sensitive to as little as 0.2 fmol of peptide. Increases in hemolymph CHH were observed under conditions of acute hypoxia, elevated temperature, and altered salinity. In addition, elevated CHH concentrations were observed in Norway lobsters ("Nephrops norvegicus") that were parasitized with the dinoflagellate "Hematodinium" sp. Stress proteins, also known as heat-shock proteins (HSPs), comprise a highly conserved class of proteins that display elevated transcription during periods of stress. Using homologous molecular probes, the author and collaborators have examined the influence of heat-shock, osmotic stress, and the molt cycle upon HSP expression at the protein and mRNA levels. They observed a significant elevation in HSP mRNA expression after 1 hr of heat-shock or after 0.5 hr of osmotic stress. When comparing claw and abdominal muscles during molting, they observed a tissue-specific HSP response. Quantification of these different stress responses may serve as early indicators of the degradation of environmental health.
